questions.text: What is the recommended treatment protocol for plasmodium vivax infection in pregnant females in the 1st trimester with complaints of headache and fever?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloroquine

 

Explanation:

 

For plasmodium vivax infection in pregnant females, especially in the first trimester, the recommended treatment is chloroquine.

 

For vivax and ovale malaria, the treatment of choice is chloroquine along with primaquine. However, in pregnancy primaquine is contraindicated.

 

Since the specifically asks about the treatment protocol for a pregnant female in the first trimester with vivax malaria, the appropriate treatment would be chloroquine alone, without primaquine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ART combined therapy - This option is incorrect because artemisinin-based combination therapy (ART) is the treatment of choice for falciparum and malariae malaria, not vivax malaria in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Quinine - This option is incorrect because quinine is not the recommended treatment for vivax malaria in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Chloroquine + Primaquine - This option is incorrect because primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment Protocol

choices.text: Unconscious with Pulse present Breathing present
Conscious with Pulse present Breathing present

questions.text: This position is given in which patients? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconscious with Pulse present Breathing present

 

The position shown in the image is the recovery position. This position is used for unconscious patients who have a pulse and are breathing adequately. The purpose of placing a patient in the recovery position is to maintain a clear airway and prevent aspiration by allowing any fluids (like saliva or vomit) to drain from the mouth. This position also helps prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulse absent, Breathing present: If a patient is pulseless, they are in cardiac arrest and require immediate CPR, not placement in the recovery position.

 

Option B. Pulse absent, Breathing absent: In the absence of both pulse and breathing, the patient requires immediate CPR and advanced life support, not the recovery position.

 

Option D. Conscious with Pulse present, Breathing present: A conscious patient who is breathing and has a pulse would not need to be placed in the recovery position. They should be kept comfortable and monitored, but no special positioning is necessary unless they become unconscious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for unconscious patients who have a pulse and are breathing, to maintain airway patency and prevent aspiration.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to OPD at PHC with gum bleeding. This may be due to deficiency of (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin C

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin C deficiency leads to a condition known as scurvy.

 

Scurvy is characterized by impaired collagen synthesis, resulting in symptoms such as delayed wound healing, gum bleeding, and in severe cases, bone fractures. Collagen is essential for maintaining the integrity of connective tissues, and its deficiency directly affects the strength and healing capacity of tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Deficiency typically leads to night blindness and xerophthalmia, not gum bleeding.

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: Deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms but does not cause gum bleeding.

 

Option D. Vitamin E: Deficiency is rare and mainly results in neurological problems and hemolytic anemia, not gum bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as delayed wound healing, gum bleeding, and potential bone fractures.

 

Note - James Lind gave the concept that Citrus fruits can prevent/cure Scurvy (Later found to be due to deficiency of Vitamin-C/Ascorbic Acid).

questions.text: In a diabetic patient, the following lesions are present in the armpit. What would be observed during a Wood's lamp examination? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coral red fluorescence.

 

  • The clinical scenario of a diabetic patient, along with the observed hyperpigmented lesion in axilla strongly suggests erythrasma.
  • Coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination is the characteristic finding in this disease.

 

 

Erythrasma

 

  • It is a skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with diabetes and weakened immune systems and is associated with factors such as obesity, excessive sweating, and poor hygiene.
  • The characteristic feature of erythrasma is the presence of hyperpigmented patches that are typically asymptomatic. These patches commonly appear in areas like the axilla, groin, intergluteal, and sub-mammary regions.
  • The coral pink fluorescence observed during Wood's lamp examination is a defining feature of erythrasma and is caused by coproporphyrin III, a pigment produced by the bacterium.

 

 

  • Wood's lamp uses ultraviolet wavelength light at 365nm (320-400nm) with a peak at 365nm. The filter of the Wood's lamp is composed of Barium silicate and 9% Nickel oxide.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Yellow fluorescence: Often seen with Pityriasis versicolor, which fluoresces yellow or apple green due to the presence of tryptophan metabolites produced by Malassezia species.

 

Option C. Blue fluorescence: Not commonly associated with bacterial or fungal infections of the skin but may appear in certain conditions unrelated to common skin infections.

 

Option D. Green fluorescence: Typically observed with Pseudomonas infections or some cases of Tinea capitis caused by fungi that produce substances that fluoresce green.

 

Additional Information

 

Table: Various diseases & their colour on woods lamp examination

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Wood's lamp uses UVA light with a wavelength of 365nm (320-400 nm) for the diagnosis of various skin conditions based on the fluorescence characteristics of the skin under this specific range of ultraviolet light.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.20

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 26 Page no 26.40

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with weakness in his lower limbs and rash over the eyelids. The biopsy shows inflammation of the muscle. What is the finding shown in the image below? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gottron's papules

 

  • The finding shown in the image is Gottron's papules.
  • The given scenario of a patient with weakness, rash on eyelids (Heliotrope Rash), muscle inflammation, and presence of Gottron's papules which are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis, especially in the paediatric population, known as Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM).
  • These are erythematous to violaceous papules or plaques found over bony prominences, particularly the knuckles, elbows, knees, and toes.

 

Other features associated with Dermatomyositis are:

 

The Gottron's sign

 

  • It is the distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.

 

 

Gottron's sign: seen in the above image

 

Other Options: 

 

Option C. Heliotrope rash

 

  • It is another characteristic finding of dermatomyositis, presenting as an erythematous to violaceous rash on the upper eyelids, often accompanied by periorbital edema.

 

 

Image showing Heliotrope rash:

 

  • While the patient has a rash over the eyelids, the image does not show this area.

 

Option B. Shawl sign or V-sign:

 

  • Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as seen in the image below

 

 

  • Periungual telangiectasias: enlarged capillaries in the nail folds.

 

 

  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

 

 

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Option D. Scleroderma:

 

  • It is a connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and tightening, which can also involve internal organs. The lesions in scleroderma are not typically papular as shown in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In juvenile dermatomyositis, Gottron's papules are erythematous to violaceous raised lesions typically found over the extensor surfaces of joints and serve as a key clinical marker for the disease.

questions.text: A hair shaft with arthroconidia is seen in the image below. Identify the fungi associated with it? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microsporum

 

The image shows a hair shaft containing arthroconidia, which are fungal spores that develop within or on the surface of the hair. The key points to consider are:

 

  • Endothrix and Ectothrix: Endothrix refers to fungal infections where the spores (arthroconidia) are found inside the hair shaft, while ectothrix refers to infections where spores are found on the outside of the hair shaft.
  • Microsporum: Although typically associated with ectothrix infections, in this scenario, it is the most appropriate answer given that the other options are less likely to produce this specific pattern.

 

Despite Microsporum generally being linked to ectothrix infections, it remains the best answer in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichosporon: Incorrect because it is associated with white piedra and does not form arthroconidia within the hair shaft.

 

Option C. Candida: Incorrect because Candida does not cause infections within the hair shaft; it is primarily involved in mucosal and cutaneous infections.

 

Option D. Epidermophyton: Incorrect because this fungus does not infect hair; it is more commonly associated with skin and nail infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microsporum can be associated with fungal infections of the hair shaft, particularly in cases where arthroconidia are observed. Even though it is more commonly linked with ectothrix infections, it is the best option among the given choices for this scenario

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of the family cycle.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Formation → extension → contraction → dissolution

 

Explanation:

 

The family cycle consists of the following 6 stages in the correct sequence:

 

  1. Formation: From marriage until the birth of the first child.
  2. Extension: From the birth of the first child until the birth of the last child.
  3. Complete Extension - From the birth of the last child until the first child leaves home
  4. Contraction: from first child leaves home to the last child leaves home
  5. Complete contraction: from last child leave home to the death of first spouse
  6. Dissolution: From the death of the first spouse until the death of the surviving spouse.

 

The correct sequence is formation, extension, contraction, and finally, dissolution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the family cycle is formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction and dissolution, representing the stages from marriage to the death of the surviving spouse.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive device shown in the photograph: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lippes Loop

 

The contraceptive device shown in the photograph is the Lippes Loop, which is an inert, non-medicated intrauterine device (IUD). The Lippes Loop is categorized as a first-generation IUD and is one of the earliest forms of intrauterine contraception. Unlike modern IUDs, which often contain copper or hormones, the Lippes Loop does not contain any active substances.

 

It is made of plastic and has a distinctive S-shape, which was designed to fit within the uterus. However, due to its high failure rate compared to newer, medicated IUDs, it is not commonly used today. Modern IUDs are typically either copper-based (second-generation) or hormone-releasing (third-generation), which offer better efficacy and safety profiles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper T 380 A: This is a second-generation IUD that contains copper. It is more effective than the Lippes Loop due to its medicated nature, which creates an inflammatory reaction toxic to sperm and eggs, preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Options B. Mirena and D. Levonorgestrel IUD (LNG-IUD): Mirena is a third-generation, hormone-releasing IUD that contains levonorgestrel, measuring 32 × 32 mm placed for up to 5 years

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lippes Loop is an older, non-medicated, inert IUD that was once widely used but has been largely replaced by more effective copper and hormone-releasing IUDs in modern contraceptive practice.

questions.text: What does phase III represent in the below image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alveolar plateau

 

The image represents a capnography waveform, which displays the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air. Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the period during exhalation where CO2 levels plateau as alveolar gas is exhaled. This phase reflects the CO2 concentration from the alveoli, which is relatively stable until the end of expiration. The end of phase III corresponds to the end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2), a key measurement in monitoring ventilation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the exhalation of alveolar gas and is used to determine the end-tidal CO2 level.

questions.text: The condition shown below can be treated by supplementation of which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nicotinamide

 

The image depicts a classic case of pellagra, which is a condition caused by a deficiency in Vitamin B3 (Niacin). Pellagra is characterized by the "3 D's": Dermatitis, Diarrhea, and Dementia. If untreated, it can lead to death. The dermatitis seen in pellagra is often referred to as Castle’s necklace, a photodermatitis pattern appearing in areas exposed to sunlight, such as around the neck, as shown in the image.

 

The treatment for pellagra involves the supplementation of Nicotinamide, which is a form of Vitamin B3. Nicotinamide helps correct the deficiency and alleviate the symptoms of pellagra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not related to the condition shown in the image. Vitamin A deficiency typically leads to bitot's spots on the eyes and phrynoderma (a rough, bumpy skin condition), but not the dermatitis associated with pellagra.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine is Vitamin B6, which is involved in many bodily functions, but its deficiency does not cause pellagra. Instead, pyridoxine deficiency may result in symptoms such as dermatitis, depression, confusion, and weakened immune function, but it does not cause the specific dermatitis seen in pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to a condition known as scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums, delayed wound healing, and corkscrew hair. The skin changes in scurvy are different from those in pellagra and do not involve the characteristic "necklace" pattern dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by the "3 D's" (Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia), is caused by a deficiency in Vitamin B3 (Niacin) and is treated with Nicotinamide supplementation.

questions.text: A gymnasium owner found that people drank ice tea while exercising in his gym. He further mentioned that the subsequent weight loss was solely due to ice tea. This is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spurious association

 

A spurious association occurs when a relationship between two variables is falsely inferred, often due to the presence of a confounding variable. In this case, the gym owner observed that people drank ice tea while exercising and then experienced weight loss. However, the weight loss is actually due to the exercise, not the ice tea.

 

The gym owner incorrectly attributed the weight loss solely to the consumption of ice tea, which is a classic example of a spurious association—where the real cause (exercise) is overlooked or ignored, and an unrelated factor (ice tea) is wrongly identified as the cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct association: This would imply a straightforward cause-and-effect relationship; such as exercise leading directly to weight loss. This is not applicable here because the claim was that ice tea, not exercise, caused the weight loss.

 

Option B. Indirect association: An indirect association occurs when the relationship between two variables is mediated by one or more additional variables. For example, exercise might lead to increased metabolism, which in turn leads to weight loss. This is not applicable in this scenario because the weight loss is directly due to exercise, not mediated by another factor like ice tea.

 

Option D. No association: This would imply that there is no relationship at all between the variables. However, in this scenario, the gym owner has incorrectly claimed an association, which makes it a spurious association rather than no association.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A spurious association occurs when a relationship is wrongly inferred between two variables due to a confounding factor. In this case, the gym owner incorrectly attributed weight loss to ice tea consumption rather than the true cause, which is exercise.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes for a follow-up visit after a vasectomy. How long should he and his partner continue using a barrier method of contraception after the procedure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 12-16 Weeks

 

Following Vasectomy, the use of barrier methods of contraception are recommended for 3 months or 12 weeks, as even though it is a permanent method, the spermatozoa takes up to three months to clear out from the tract/ ejaculatory ducts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-vasectomy, it is recommended to continue using a barrier contraceptive method for 12-16 weeks to ensure that all remaining sperm have been cleared from the ejaculatory ducts.

questions.text: Criteria for FRU include all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24-hour MTP facility

 

Explanation:

 

The criteria for a functional First Referral Unit (FRU) include:

 

  1. 24-hour delivery services
  2. Emergency obstetric care, including surgical intervention (implying surgical intervention is a criterion)
  3. Blood storage facility
  4. RTI/STI management
  5. Newborn care
  6. Care of sick children
  7. Full range of family planning services, including safe abortion services (but not explicitly 24-hour MTP facility)
  8. Essential laboratory services
  9. Transport facility

 

The criteria "not included" for an FRU is the availability of a 24-hour MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) facility. It states that while 24-hour delivery services are available, a 24-hour MTP facility is not explicitly listed as a criterion for an FRU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a functional First Referral Unit (FRU), the criteria include 24-hour delivery services, emergency obstetric care (including surgical intervention), blood storage facility, RTI/STI management, newborn care, care of sick children, family planning services, essential laboratory services, and transport facility. However, the availability of a 24-hour MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) facility is not explicitly a criterion for an FRU.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is found to be associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bitot’s spots

 

Vitamin A deficiency is a significant public health issue, especially in developing countries, and it is associated with various ocular manifestations collectively known as xerophthalmia. One of the most specific and classic signs of Vitamin A deficiency is the presence of Bitot’s spots. These are foamy, whitish accumulations on the conjunctiva, typically located on the temporal side of the eye. They are caused by the buildup of keratin due to the lack of Vitamin A, which is essential for maintaining the health of the conjunctiva and cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: This is a common, benign, yellowish growth on the conjunctiva that is unrelated to Vitamin A deficiency. It is associated with aging and UV exposure.

 

Option C. Pterygium: This is a growth of fleshy tissue that may extend onto the cornea. It is linked to UV exposure and chronic irritation but is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Stocker's line: This is an iron deposit line seen at the leading edge of a pterygium and is not related to Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO Classification of Xerophthalmia

questions.text: Dermatitis Herpetiformis as a skin manifestation is seen in cases of? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Celiac Sprue

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic skin condition characterized by intensely itchy blisters and raised red patches. It is strongly associated with Celiac disease, also known as Celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. This autoimmune disorder is triggered by the ingestion of gluten, leading to damage in the small intestine and associated skin manifestations like dermatitis herpetiformis. The presence of IgA antibodies against transglutaminase in both the gut and the skin is a key feature linking these conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Ulcerative Colitis and D. Crohn's disease: This is an inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the colon and rectum. It is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis but can be linked to other skin manifestations like pyoderma gangrenosum and erythema nodosum.

 

  • Erythema Nodosum is characterized by tender red nodules, typically appearing on the shins, and frequently associated with IBD.

 

Option C. Whipple's disease: This is a rare bacterial infection that affects multiple systems in the body, including the gastrointestinal tract. It does not have an association with dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a specific skin manifestation associated with Celiac disease and should prompt the evaluation for gluten sensitivity enteropathy in affected patients.

questions.text: In which of the following devices is Murphy's eye seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endotracheal tube

 

Murphy's eye is a characteristic feature seen in many endotracheal tubes:

 

 

  • Murphy's eye is a hole located on the side of the distal end of an endotracheal tube. It acts as a safety feature.
  • The primary purpose of Murphy's eye is to provide an alternate route for ventilation in case the main lumen of the tube becomes obstructed, either by being pressed against the tracheal wall or by accumulated secretions or blood.
  • In addition to ensuring continued ventilation, Murphy's eye also reduces the risk of trauma to the tracheal mucosa by reducing suction against the tracheal wall when the main tip is occluded.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal airway: This device does not have a Murphy's eye. It is a simple tube inserted into the nasal passage to maintain an open airway.

 

Option B. Laryngoscope: This is a tool used for visualizing the larynx during intubation and does not have a Murphy's eye.

 

Option C. Bronchoscope: This is an instrument used for visualizing the inside of the airways and does not have a Murphy's eye.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Murphy's eye is an important safety feature found in endotracheal tubes, providing an alternative pathway for ventilation and reducing the risk of mucosal trauma.

choices.text: Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and aerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and night time
Aerobic during day time and night time

questions.text: A civil engineer in Kerala is designing a wastewater treatment facility for a growing town. He considers implementing an oxidation pond, a natural wastewater treatment system. Which of the following best describes the microbial activity of the oxidation pond? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time.

 

  • Oxidation ponds uses aerobic method during day time and anaerobic during night time.
  • Oxidation pond also known as - waste stabilization pond/redox pond/sewage lagoons
  • Oxidation ponds or sewage lagoons are a popular method of purifying sewage for small communities. 
  • These are open shallow pools of around 1-1.5 m depth with an inlet and outlet. 
  • The oxidation ponds have algae, types of saprophytic bacteria and sunlight-which helps in aerobic sewage treatment during day time and anaerobic treatment of sewage during night time. 
  • The effluent can be used for land irrigation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxidation ponds utilize aerobic microbial activity during the day and anaerobic activity at night to treat wastewater effectively.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with poor wound healing and hyperpigmentation around her wounds, along with swollen and bleeding gums, follows a restrictive diet avoiding many fruits and vegetables. Given her symptoms, which pairs of elements or compounds are critical for proper collagen synthesis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ascorbic acid and copper

 

Vitamin C is also known as Ascorbic acid. It is needed for hydroxylation of lysine and proline during collagen synthesis. Apart from that Copper is also required for the enzymatic function of lysyl oxidase, an enzyme important for cross-linking collagen fibers, providing strength and stability to the collagen matrix.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zinc and Copper: While both are important minerals, zinc is more involved in wound healing and immune function rather than direct collagen synthesis.

 

Option C. Ascorbic acid and Iron: Iron is important for overall health and the function of some enzymes, but it is not directly involved in collagen synthesis like copper.

 

Option D. Iodine and Iron: These elements are primarily involved in thyroid function and oxygen transport, respectively, and do not play a direct role in collagen synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For proper collagen synthesis, ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) and copper are critical elements.

questions.text: Serology of IPV vaccine strains is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1, type 2, type 3

 

Explanation:

 

The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) contains all three strains of the poliovirus: Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3. Although India switched from the trivalent Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) to the bivalent OPV (containing only Type 1 and Type 3) as part of the global switch program in April 2016.

 

The IPV introduced in the national immunization schedule still contains all three poliovirus strains. It is a trivalent vaccine, containing Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3 strains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) introduced in the national immunization schedule of India contains all three strains of the poliovirus: Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3, making it a trivalent vaccine.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of the Demographic cycle in the correct chronological sequence: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Low stationary
  2. High stationary
  3. Declining
  4. Early expanding
  5. Late expanding
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 2 4 5 1 3

 

The Demographic Transition Model describes the stages a country goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. The stages of the demographic cycle in correct chronological order are:

 

2. High Stationary : This is the first stage characterized by high birth and high death rates, leading to a stable population. It reflects pre-industrial societies with limited medical care and poor living conditions.

 

4. Early Expanding: In this stage, death rates start to decline due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and nutrition, while birth rates remain high, resulting in rapid population growth.

 

5. Late Expanding : Birth rates begin to fall as societies become more urbanized and access to contraception improves, but the population continues to grow, albeit at a slower rate.

 

1. Low Stationary : Both birth and death rates are low, stabilizing the population size. This stage reflects advanced economies with high living standards and access to family planning.

 

3. Declining : In the final stage, the birth rate falls below the death rate, leading to a declining population. This stage is seen in highly developed countries with aging populations and very low fertility rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the demographic cycle stages is: High Stationary, Early Expanding, Late Expanding, Low Stationary, and Declining.

questions.text: While preparing a slide for histopathological examination (HPE), a box-like gross appearance is seen in the scanner view. In which of the following conditions is this seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morphea

 

The box-like or squared-off appearance observed in the histopathological slide is characteristic of Morphea, also known as localized scleroderma. This appearance results from marked sclerosis of the collagen throughout the reticular dermis, which can sometimes extend to the subcutaneous fat. Morphea is a type of localized scleroderma where the skin becomes hard and tight due to excessive collagen deposition. This histological feature is distinctive and helps differentiate Morphea from other conditions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen nitidus: This condition typically shows a "claw clutching ball" appearance histologically, where inflammatory cells are tightly packed within the dermal papillae. This appearance is different from the box-like structure seen in Morphea.

 

 

Option B. Lichen planopilaris: Lichen planopilaris is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration around hair follicles, leading to scarring alopecia. Hair follicles or their remnants would be visible in the histological image, which is not the case in the presented slide.

 

 

Option D. Lichen amyloidosis: This condition would usually show deposits of amyloid, often highlighted with a polarized microscope, creating a distinctive pattern, but not the box-like appearance seen here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Morphea, a localized form of scleroderma, is identified by a box-like or squared-off appearance on histopathological slides due to marked collagen sclerosis in the dermis.

questions.text: Ebola virus comes under which Biosafety level category as given by WHO? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4.

 

Ebola virus requires the highest level of containment, BSL-4, due to its extreme pathogenicity and the severe risk it poses to both laboratory personnel and the community.

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies infectious agents into four Biosafety Levels (BSLs), based on their potential to cause disease and the precautions required to handle them safely:

 

  • Biosafety Level 1 (BSL-1): This is for work with low-risk microbes that pose minimal threat to laboratory workers and the environment, such as non-pathogenic strains of E. coli, non-pathogenic staphylococcus, Saccharomyces cerevisiae (a type of yeast) and Bacillus subtilis.
  • Biosafety Level 2 (BSL-2): This level is appropriate for work involving agents that pose moderate hazards to personnel and the environment. This includes pathogens like Pathogenic E coli, pathogenic Staphylococcus aureus, hepatitis viruses A B & C, HIV, toxoplasma, malaria (plasmodium falciparum) and salmonella.
  • Biosafety Level 3 (BSL-3): This level is used for agents that can cause serious or potentially lethal diseases through inhalation, such as rickettsial diseases, Q fever, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Psittacosis, brucella, yellow fever virus, Yersinia pestis, EEEV and corona virus (SARS-CoV-2).
  • Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4): This is the highest level of biosafety and is used for handling agents that pose a high risk of life-threatening disease for which there are no vaccines or treatments. The Ebola virus, Marburg virus, Lassa virus, Nipah virus, flavivirus, and Lassa virus, falls under this category due to its high fatality rate and the absence of effective treatments.

 

Note - For COVID-19 both biosafety level 2 and 3 are correct; 2 is for routine testing & diagnostic testing, and 3 is for culture and virus isolation

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ebola virus is classified under Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) by WHO, indicating it is one of the most dangerous pathogens requiring the highest level of containment.

questions.text: Preferable time for IUCD insertion in a 28-year-old woman who has just delivered a healthy newborn. It was a normal vaginal delivery. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Up to 48 hours

 

Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) insertion timing can be categorized into three main periods:

 

  1. During Menstruation: IUCD insertion during menstruation is preferred within the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle to ensure the woman is not pregnant and to ease insertion due to the open cervical os.
  2. Immediate Postpartum: The best time for postpartum IUCD insertion is within the first 48 hours after delivery. If not done within this window, insertion can be performed up to 1 week postpartum. This timing is optimal as the cervix is dilated, and there is a reduced risk of expulsion compared to later periods.
  3. Post Puerperal: If IUCD insertion is not performed immediately postpartum, the next preferred timing is 6 to 8 weeks after delivery when the uterus has involuted and stabilized.

 

For this question, since the woman has just delivered, the most precise and preferred time is within the first 48 hours postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most preferable time for IUCD insertion after a normal vaginal delivery is within the first 48 hours postpartum to take advantage of the naturally dilated cervix and minimize expulsion risk

questions.text: In the IMNCI guidelines for the management of diarrhea, the color code for some dehydration is:(FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Yellow

 

Explanation:

 

In the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI) guidelines, diarrhea dehydration is classified into three categories:

 

  • No dehydration – Green – Home management
  • Some dehydration – Yellow – PHC based (MO) – 2 out of 4 criteria

 

Four criteria:

 

  1. Restlessness
  2. Irritability
  3. Sunken eyes
  4. Skin pinch goes back slowly

 

  • Severe dehydration – Pink - Is diagnosed based on the presence of two out of four criteria:

 

  1. Lethargy
  2. Unconsciousness
  3. Sunken eyes
  4. Skin pinch goes back very slowly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the IMNCI guidelines for the management of diarrhea, the color code yellow represents "some dehydration," which is diagnosed based on the presence of two out of four criteria: restlessness, irritability, sunken eyes, and skin pinch goes back slowly.

questions.text: A young boy came to Derma OPD with complaints of severe itching at night. On examination, burrows are seen over intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits. The disease is transmitted by? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mite

 

The boy's symptoms, including severe nocturnal itching and the presence of burrows in specific body areas (intertriginous regions, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits), are classic signs of scabies. Scabies is a skin condition caused by infestation with the itch mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis. The mite burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, especially at night. The areas affected (often referred to as the circle of Hebra) are characteristic for scabies.

 

 

Circle of Hebra

 

 

Mites

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Louse: Lice infestation, known as pediculosis, typically causes itching but does not present with burrows in the skin or nocturnal itching. Lice infest hair and clothing rather than burrowing into the skin.

 

Option B. Tick: Ticks are ectoparasites that attach to the skin and can transmit various diseases, such as Lyme disease. However, they do not cause the characteristic burrows or intense nocturnal itching seen in scabies.

 

Option D. Flea: Flea bites cause itchy red spots, primarily on the lower legs, but fleas do not burrow into the skin or cause the described distribution of burrows.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scabies is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis, which burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, particularly at night, and burrows in characteristic areas such as the axillae, umbilicus, and between the digits.

questions.text: What is true about this position? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sniffing position for intubation

 

The image illustrates the "sniffing position," which is the ideal position for tracheal intubation. In this position, the patient’s head is elevated and extended at the atlanto-occipital joint, aligning the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes. This alignment facilitates a direct line of sight during laryngoscopy, making intubation easier. The sniffing position is a standard recommendation for intubating patients under general anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideal position for Bougie insertion: The sniffing position is primarily recognized for its role in enhancing the view during direct laryngoscopy.

 

Option C. Ideal position for Neurosurgery: This option is incorrect because the sniffing position is not typically used for neurosurgical procedures. Neurosurgery often requires specific head and neck positioning to optimize access to the brain or spine, which differs from the sniffing position.

 

Option D. Neck position for intubation: The term "neck position for intubation" is too vague. The correct terminology for the position depicted in the image is the "sniffing position," which specifically describes the head and neck alignment optimal for intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sniffing position aligns the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, making it the ideal position for tracheal intubation

questions.text: A male patient with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse four days back came with complaints of painful urethral discharge. What is the treatment of choice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cefixime 400 mg stat

 

The patient's history of unprotected sexual intercourse and the rapid onset of painful urethral discharge are highly indicative of gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Gonococcal urethritis typically presents with dysuria (painful urination) and a purulent (pus-like) discharge from the urethra.

 

The treatment of choice for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat. Cefixime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This treatment is preferred due to its efficacy in eradicating the infection and its convenience as a single-dose therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg BD x 2 weeks: Doxycycline is typically used for treating chlamydial infections, which can co-occur with gonorrhea but is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea itself. Additionally, a two-week course is usually prescribed for chlamydia, not gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Benzathine Penicillin: Benzathine Penicillin is primarily used for treating syphilis, not gonorrhea. Syphilis and gonorrhea are different sexually transmitted infections with distinct treatments.

 

Option D. Azithromycin 1 gm stat: Azithromycin can be used in the treatment of chlamydial infections, often alongside treatment for gonorrhea to cover potential co-infection. However, it is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea when given alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat. This treatment is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacteria responsible for the infection.

questions.text: A 2 years old child present to OPD at PHC with complaints of cough and coryza. On examination, fever and conjunctivitis are present. Mother told that the rash started behind ear pinna then came over the trunk. Most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measles

 

Explanation:

 

Measles is characterized by symptoms like cough, coryza, fever, and conjunctivitis. The crucial diagnostic clue is the rash starting from behind the ear (retroauricular origin) and spreading to the trunk. This progression, coupled with the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa opposite the second molar before the rash appears, confirms measles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dengue: Typically presents with high fever and severe headache, pain behind the eyes, muscle and joint pains; rash is not primarily retroauricular.

 

Option B. Chikungunya: Presents with fever and severe joint pain but lacks the characteristic early symptoms and rash pattern of measles.

 

Option D. Rubella: While it can cause rash and fever, the rash usually starts on the face and spreads downward, and it lacks the specific Koplik spots associated with measles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles should be suspected in children presenting with cough, coryza, fever, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic rash starting from behind the ear, spreading to the trunk, alongside the presence of Koplik spots.

questions.text: A particular community population has been consuming Maize as a staple diet for years. The vitamin deficiency most likely to be seen in this population is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Niacin

 

Maize, commonly consumed as a staple food in many communities, is deficient in the amino acid tryptophan, which is crucial for the synthesis of niacin (Vitamin B3) in the body. Niacin can be synthesized endogenously from tryptophan at a conversion rate of 60 mg of tryptophan to 1 mg of niacin. However, when maize is a primary dietary component, the body lacks sufficient tryptophan, leading to niacin deficiency.

 

Moreover, maize is high in leucine, an amino acid that inhibits the conversion of tryptophan to niacin via the kynurenine pathway. This combination of low tryptophan and high leucine content makes niacin deficiency prevalent in populations consuming maize as a staple diet, resulting in pellagra.

 

Pellagra is characterized by the “4 Ds”: Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia, and Death if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine deficiency is typically associated with polished rice consumption, not maize. It leads to conditions like beriberi.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency, though possible, is not specifically linked to maize consumption. It typically results from general dietary insufficiency of various foods, not specific to maize.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin: Cyanocobalamin (Vitamin B12) deficiency is generally seen in populations with low intake of animal products and is not related to maize consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maize as a staple diet leads to niacin deficiency due to its low tryptophan and high leucine content, resulting in pellagra.

 

Note – Leucine is known as pellagrogenic aminoacid in India

questions.text: Benzathine penicillin is given for the treatment of rheumatic fever. This is which level of prevention? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Secondary level

 

Secondary prevention involves the early detection and treatment of a disease to prevent its progression.

 

In the context of rheumatic fever, if a child has already developed the condition, benzyl benzathine penicillin (BBP) is administered to prevent further complications, such as rheumatic heart disease. This treatment is given in regular doses (1.2 million units in adults or 0.6 million units in children; every 3 weeks) over a period of 5 years or until the child is 18 years old, whichever comes later. This approach is aimed at treating the condition and preventing its worsening, which characterizes secondary prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primordial level: This level focuses on preventing the emergence of risk factors in a population. It is not relevant to the treatment of an existing condition like rheumatic fever.

 

Option B. Primary level: This involves preventing the onset of disease in at-risk individuals. In this context, primary prevention would involve giving penicillin to prevent the initial occurrence of rheumatic fever in a child with a streptococcal sore throat.

 

Dose of BBP - 1.2 million units in adults or 0.6 million units in children; single dose; IM stat.

 

Option D. Tertiary level: Tertiary prevention is aimed at reducing the impact of an ongoing illness that has lasting effects. This would involve rehabilitation and managing chronic complications, which is not the primary aim of benzathine penicillin treatment in rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary prevention involves the treatment of existing conditions, such as rheumatic fever, to prevent further complications.

questions.text: The defined population norm for Urban-Primary health centre in our country is one such centre per: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 per 50,000

 

In India, the population norm for establishing a UPHC is one center per 50,000 population. These centers are intended to provide primary healthcare services in urban areas, addressing the healthcare needs of urban populations efficiently.

 

The UPHCs are equipped to deliver a range of health services, including preventive, promotive, curative, and rehabilitative care.

 

In UPHC, one Urban Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) per 10,000 population, and one Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) per 1,000 to 2,500 population.

 

Remember –

 

Population norm for rural PHC

 

  • 1 per 30,000 populations in plain area
  • 1 per 20,000 populations in tribal and hilly areas

 

Educational Objective:

 

The population norm for establishing an Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) in India is one center per 50,000 populations.

questions.text: An adolescent male came with complaints of lesions all over the face and back, which were predominantly comedones. What is the most effective treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systemic doxycycline

 

Acne vulgaris, particularly when it predominantly presents with comedones, is a common condition in adolescents. Comedones are the primary lesions in acne, which can progress to inflammatory lesions if not adequately managed. Systemic doxycycline is an effective treatment for moderate to severe acne, particularly when it involves both comedones and inflammatory lesions like papules and pustules. Doxycycline acts as an antibacterial and anti-inflammatory agent, which helps reduce the bacteria responsible for acne (Propionibacterium acnes) and the inflammation associated with acne lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Systemic isotretinoin: Isotretinoin is a powerful systemic retinoid used primarily for severe, nodular cystic acne. Since the question specifies comedones without mention of nodulocystic lesions, systemic isotretinoin is not the most appropriate first-line treatment for this case.

 

Option C. Topical Dapsone: Topical Dapsone is used in the treatment of acne, particularly in inflammatory lesions. However, it may not be as effective for widespread comedones over the face and back, and topical treatments may not be feasible for extensive cases.

 

Option D. Systemic Azithromycin: While azithromycin is an antibiotic that can be used in acne treatment, it is less commonly used compared to doxycycline and is not the first-line treatment for comedonal acne. Doxycycline is preferred due to its broader use and efficacy in managing both comedonal and inflammatory acne lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic doxycycline is the most effective treatment for moderate to severe acne that involves comedones and inflammatory lesions, particularly when the condition is extensive.

questions.text: A woman who got IUCD inserted at a PHC, now presents with bleeding. What should be done by the MO? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron supplement and observation

 

Bleeding after IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) insertion is a common and typically normal physiological response. It is generally expected to subside within the first two menstrual cycles. While reassurance is important, simply reassuring the patient may not be sufficient, as persistent bleeding can lead to anemia.

 

The best approach is to supplement with iron (e.g., ferrous sulfate 200 mg TDS for 8 weeks) to prevent anemia while observing the patient. If the bleeding does not subside despite supplementation, the IUCD may need to be removed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassurance: While reassurance is important, it alone may not be enough if the bleeding persists and leads to anemia.

 

Option B. Remove IUCD: Immediate removal of the IUCD is not the first line of management unless the bleeding persists despite supplementation and observation.

 

Option C. Antibiotics and IV fluids: These are not indicated unless there is an infection or severe bleeding, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron supplementation and observation are crucial in managing post-IUCD insertion bleeding to prevent anemia. If bleeding persists, further action, such as removing the IUCD, may be necessary.

choices.text: Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts

questions.text: A 57-year-old person completed his treatment of leprosy. Two years later, he presents with a punched-out painless ulcer on his sole. What is the next best step in the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts

 

The patient is presenting with a chronic trophic ulcer, which is a common complication in patients with leprosy, particularly after the disease has been treated and the bacteria eradicated.

 

Trophic ulcers arise due to the loss of sensation (neuropathy) and autonomic disturbances leading to dry, cracked skin that is prone to injury. The patient does not feel pain, which allows the ulcer to become large and deep over time.

 

The correct management involves reducing pressure on the affected area to allow healing. This can be achieved by advising the patient to bear less weight on the affected foot and using a plaster cast or a total contact cast, which redistributes weight and protects the ulcer from further trauma.

 

 

Note –

 

  • Plantar ulceration is a common complication in lepromatous leprosy, often occurring even after the disease is arrested. Progressive fibrosis of nerves leads to 'glove and stocking' anesthesia, with loss of sensation in the limbs, particularly the plantar aspect of the foot.
  • This condition is one of the most frequent impairments in leprosy, reported in 21% to 63% of newly reported cases. The combination of loss of touch and pain, along with foot deformity, causes disproportionate weight distribution on the sole of the foot, leading to non-healing or chronic ulceration.
  • Types:
    • Acute ulcers: Present with acute infection and severe acute inflammation.
    • Chronic ulcers: Long-standing ulcers without signs of acute inflammation.
    • Complicated chronic ulcers: These ulcers result from the spread of infection to deeper structures like the underlying bone, joint, or tendon sheath.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restart MDT: Multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy is used to treat active infections caused by Mycobacterium leprae. However, in this case, the patient has completed treatment, and the ulcer is due to neuropathy, not an active infection. Therefore, restarting MDT is not necessary and would not address the ulcer.

 

Option C. Aggressive Debridement with IV antibiotics: Aggressive debridement and IV antibiotics are typically indicated for infected ulcers or those with acute signs of inflammation. In this case, the ulcer is chronic and not primarily due to infection, so this approach is not warranted.

 

Option D. Amputation: Amputation is a last resort, reserved for cases where ulcers have led to severe, life-threatening complications such as osteomyelitis that cannot be managed by other means. This is not the case here, and such an extreme measure is not necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of chronic trophic ulcers in leprosy, reducing pressure on the ulcerated area through weight redistribution, such as with a plaster cast, is essential to promote healing and prevent further complication

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a 2-month history of persistent diarrhea, a worsening rash on his hands and neck, and episodes of memory lapses and confusion. His diet primarily consists of untreated maize (corn). Which vitamin deficiency is he most likely suffering from? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Niacin

 

The patient's symptoms and dietary history suggest he is suffering from pellagra, which is caused by a deficiency in niacin (Vitamin B3). Pellagra is characterized by the "4 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and death if untreated.

 

Symptom:

 

4Ds: Dermatitis, dementia, diarrhea, and death

 

Dermatitis is seen around the neck of the person k/a Cassal’s necklace.

 

Consumption of untreated maize as a primary dietary staple is a recognized risk factor for pellagra because maize contains niacin in a form that is not bioavailable unless treated with lime or alkali (a process known as nixtamalization).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, characterized by sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, cracks or sores on the outsides of the lips (cheilosis) and at the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis), and a moist, scaly skin inflammation (seborrheic dermatitis).

 

Option C. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Deficiency causes beriberi, which can present as dry beriberi (neuropathy and muscle weakness) or wet beriberi (cardiovascular symptoms), and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (neurological symptoms).

 

Option D. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Deficiency can lead to microcytic anemia, dermatitis, depression, confusion, and convulsions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, caused by niacin deficiency, presents with a triad of symptoms: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. A diet primarily consisting of untreated maize can increase the risk of this deficiency.

questions.text: All of the following are true about NF-1 EXCEPT: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal recessive

 

The correct answer is autosomal recessive. Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1) is an autosomal dominant disorder, not autosomal recessive. It is characterized by multiple café-au-lait macules, Lisch nodules, and an increased risk of developing various tumors, including optic gliomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Optic glioma: This is true. Patients with NF-1 have an increased risk of developing optic gliomas.

 

Option C. CALM (Cafe Au Lait Macules): This is true. Café-au-lait macules are a common feature of NF-1.

 

Option D. Lisch nodules: This is true. Lisch nodules are iris hamartomas commonly seen in patients with NF-1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by features such as café-au-lait macules, Lisch nodules, and optic gliomas. It is important to remember that it is not autosomal recessive.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes conjunctival xerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin A

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin A deficiency leads to a condition called xerophthalmia, which causes conjunctival xerosis, also known as dry eye. Xerophthalmia can be classified into two types: primary and secondary.

 

Primary xerophthalmia has five categories:

 

  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis (dry eye)
  • X1B: Bitot's spots (a specific manifestation)
  • X2: Corneal xerosis
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration
  • X3B: Keratomalacia

 

Secondary manifestations of xerophthalmia include:

 

  • XN: Night blindness
  • XF: Xerophthalmic fundus
  • XS: Xerophthalmic scarring

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with megaloblastic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the "4 D's" (diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death). It does not directly cause conjunctival xerosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia and neural tube defects in developing fetuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency causes xerophthalmia, which leads to conjunctival xerosis (dry eye) and other ocular manifestations, including Bitot's spots, corneal xerosis, corneal ulceration, and keratomalacia.

questions.text: Arrange in order the disaster management cycle.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Impact → response → rehabilitation → mitigation

 

Explanation:

 

The correct chronological order of the disaster management cycle is as follows:

 

5 stages -

 

  1. Impact: This is the initial stage when a disaster strikes an area, such as an earthquake, flood, or tsunami.
  2. Response: In this stage, search and rescue operations, first aid, and medical relief efforts are launched.
  3. Rehabilitation: This stage focuses on addressing water, sanitation, food supply, vector control, and other essential services.
  4. Mitigation: Efforts are made to prevent hazards or risks from turning into disasters, minimizing potential damage.
  5. Preparedness: This stage involves planning and preparation for an anticipated disaster, such as a tsunami or earthquake season.

 

The answer to this is choice A, which correctly arranges the stages as impact, response, rehabilitation, and mitigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of the disaster management cycle is impact, response, rehabilitation, mitigation, and preparedness, representing the chronological sequence of actions taken during and after a disaster.

questions.text: Case fatality rate of the disease rabies is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 100%.

 

Rabies is one of the deadliest infectious diseases, with a case fatality rate approaching 100%. This means that once clinical symptoms of rabies appear, the disease is almost always fatal, making it the highest fatality rate for any known disease.

 

The case fatality rate is calculated by dividing the number of deaths due to a disease by the number of diagnosed cases of that disease and then multiplying by 100 to express it as a percentage.

 

The reason rabies has such a high case fatality rate is due to the virus's effects on the central nervous system, leading to acute encephalitis (inflammation of the brain). Once symptoms develop, there is no effective treatment, and death usually occurs within days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case fatality rate (CFR) is used to measure the virulence of organism or killing power of a disease.
  • CFR for COVID-19 and Chickenpox is about 1%.
  • Measles has a CFR of 3%.
  • Rabies has the highest CFR at nearly 100%, with no cure available once symptoms appear.

questions.text: Relieving pressure of pop off valve in this device is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30-40 cm H2O 

 

The image shows an Ambu bag, which is used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients. The pop-off valve, also known as a pressure release valve, is a safety feature that prevents the delivery of excessive pressure to the patient's lungs. This valve is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O, which is sufficient to ventilate the patient without causing barotrauma, which is damage to the lungs from excessive pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-off valve in a manual resuscitator is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O to ensure safe and effective ventilation without causing lung damage.

questions.text: Vaccine kept at the lowest level inside an Ice lined refrigerator (ILR) at PHC: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) OPV

 

In an Ice Lined Refrigerator (ILR), which is commonly used at Primary Health Centers (PHCs) to store vaccines, the temperature varies from 2°C at the bottom to 8°C at the top. Vaccines that require colder temperatures, closer to 2°C, are stored at the lowest level of the refrigerator because cold air settles down.

 

OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine): OPV is stored at the lowest level of the ILR because it requires a colder environment. It can even tolerate freezing temperatures and can be stored in a deep freezer at -15°C to -25°C, making it suitable for the coldest section of the refrigerator.

 

  • Lyophilized vaccines like BCG, measles, and rotaviral vaccine are also stored at lower levels since they need a stable and colder temperature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BCG: While BCG is a lyophilized vaccine and is stored at a lower level, it is not specifically the answer for this question as OPV is more specifically associated with the lowest level due to its freezing tolerance.

 

Option C. DPT: DPT vaccine is stored at the upper levels of the ILR where temperatures are closer to 6-8°C. This vaccine does not require the colder conditions found at the bottom of the refrigerator.

 

Option D. Rotaviral vaccine: Similar to BCG, the rotaviral vaccine is a lyophilized vaccine stored lower in the ILR, but OPV is the more critical vaccine stored at the lowest level due to its requirement for cold and even freezing conditions.

 

Educational Objective:


OPV is stored at the lowest level of the ILR due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions, ranging from 2°C and even tolerating freezing conditions, ensuring vaccine potency and effectiveness.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of vesicular oral lesions, and on skin sample, DIF showed a fishnet pattern as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by the formation of vesicles and bullae, particularly on mucous membranes such as the oral cavity. The disease is caused by autoantibodies against desmogleins (desmosomal proteins) that hold keratinocytes together. This results in acantholysis, where keratinocytes lose their adhesion, leading to intraepidermal blister formation.

 

The direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of a biopsy from perilesional skin in pemphigus vulgaris typically shows a "fishnet" or "chicken wire" pattern, which is due to the deposition of IgG antibodies along the keratinocyte cell membranes. The image provided in the question clearly demonstrates this characteristic pattern, which is pathognomonic for pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bullous pemphigoid: This is another autoimmune blistering disorder, but it primarily affects older adults and presents with subepidermal blisters rather than intraepidermal ones. The DIF pattern in bullous pemphigoid typically shows a linear deposition of IgG and C3 along the basement membrane zone, not a fishnet pattern.

 

Option C. LIGA: This option seems to be a distractor as there is no recognized dermatological condition by this acronym. This might be a typographical error or a non-standard term, hence it is not relevant to this question.

 

Option D. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This is a chronic blistering skin condition associated with gluten sensitivity (celiac disease). The DIF pattern in dermatitis herpetiformis typically shows granular deposits of IgA at the tips of the dermal papillae, not a fishnet pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is associated with a characteristic "fishnet" pattern on direct immunofluorescence due to IgG deposition along keratinocyte cell membranes. Recognizing this pattern is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: The best type of anesthesia for pre-eclampsia is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidural anesthesia

 

The best type of anesthesia for pre-eclampsia is Epidural anesthesia (Option B).

 

Epidural anesthesia involves the injection of anesthetic agents into the epidural space of the spine. It can be titrated to the desired level of anesthesia/analgesia and can be maintained for longer periods. 

 

  • Key Advantages in the context of pre-eclampsia:
    • Avoidance of airway manipulation: As mentioned, pregnancy can present with airway challenges due to edema, short neck, and increased breast size.
    • Preservation of Airway Reflexes: There's no risk of aspiration, which is a concern in pregnant patients due to delayed gastric emptying.
    • Decreased drug passage to fetus: Fewer systemic drugs are used, which reduces the risk of placental transfer and potential neonatal depression.
    • Pain management: Effective pain control can help in reducing catecholamine levels, which can otherwise increase blood pressure further in pre-eclamptic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinal anesthesia:

 

While it provides rapid and effective anesthesia for surgeries below the abdomen, it may cause a significant drop in blood pressure, which can be concerning in patients with pre-eclampsia.

 

Option C. General anesthesia:

 

In pregnant patients, especially with conditions like pre-eclampsia, general anesthesia presents multiple challenges:

 

Airway difficulties

 

Risk of aspiration: Pregnant patients are at an increased risk of aspiration during induction and intubation due to delayed gastric emptying.

 

Drug transfer to fetus: Many anesthetic agents can cross the placenta, potentially affecting the fetus.

 

Option D. Caudal block:

 

A caudal block is a type of epidural where the anesthetic is administered at the sacral hiatus. It's typically used in pediatric patients . While it can provide good analgesia, it's not the primary choice for managing pre-eclampsia in obstetric procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural anesthesia is preferred for pre-eclampsia due to its ability to provide effective pain relief, avoid airway manipulation, and minimize drug passage to the fetus.

questions.text: As per the latest biomedical waste management guidelines in India, the following combination is incorrect? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blue container – Incineration

 

The blue container is intended for the disposal of glassware and metallic implants. According to the latest biomedical waste management guidelines in India, these items should undergo autoclaving, hydroclaving, microwaving, or chemical treatment, followed by recycling. Incineration is not a recommended method for the blue container category.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow bag – Deep burial: This is partially correct as deep burial is permitted for placentas at primary health centers, but generally, yellow bag waste is for incineration.

 

Option B. Yellow bag – Incineration: Correct as the yellow bag is primarily used for incinerating human anatomical waste, animal waste, microbiological and biotechnological waste, etc.

 

Option C. Red bag – Autoclaving: Correct as the red bag contains contaminated recyclable plastic and rubber material, which is treated via autoclaving, hydroclaving, or microwaving.

 

Additional Information

 

White container – For Sharps → autocalving/ dry heat → destruction shredding → iron foundries/ land fill/ sharp pits 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blue containers for biomedical waste should not be incinerated but treated and then recycled as per the guidelines.

questions.text: The most common cancer found among the female population in India is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Breast cancer

 

In India, breast cancer is the most common cancer affecting the female population.

 

It ranks highest in terms of incidence, prevalence, and mortality among cancers in women.

 

Breast cancer has overtaken cervical cancer, which used to be the leading cause of cancer-related morbidity among Indian women. This shift reflects changes in lifestyle, reproductive patterns, and awareness.

 

Statistically, breast cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths among Indian women, and its incidence continues to rise, making it a significant public health concern. Additionally, breast cancer is also the most common cancer when considering the total population (both male and female) combined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral and lip cancer: While oral and lip cancers are common in India, particularly due to tobacco use, they are more prevalent in males and do not surpass breast cancer in females in terms of incidence.

 

Option B. Cervical cancer: Cervical cancer was previously the most common cancer among women in India. However, breast cancer has now overtaken it in terms of both incidence and mortality.

 

Option D. Lung cancer: Lung cancer, while common, is more prevalent in males. It is not the most common cancer among females in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among the female population in India, leading in incidence, prevalence, and mortality rates. Followed by cervico-uterine cancer, ovarian cancer, lip and oral cavity cancer, and colorectal cancer, respectively.

questions.text: A person reported to OPD alongside his 32-year-old brother working in a factory. The brother was recently subjected to a test – Coproporphyrin in urine. The physician should suspect: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Lead poisoning

 

The presence of coproporphyrin in urine is commonly associated with lead exposure, making it an important screening test for lead poisoning. Coproporphyrin in urine indicates exposure to lead, but it does not confirm whether significant absorption has occurred. To determine absorption, a specific diagnostic test called Aminolevulinic Acid in Urine (ALAU) is used.

 

CPU – screening test – indicates lead Exposure - >150 mcg/L

 

ALAU – diagnostic test – indicated lead absorption - > 5mg/L

 

Elevated levels of lead in urine (>800 µg/L) signify both exposure and absorption, while levels above 700 µg/L indicate the onset of clinical symptoms.

 

Lead poisoning, also known as plumbism, is treated with chelation therapy using EDTA combined with dimercaprol, which helps remove lead from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust, common in mining, quarrying, and glass manufacturing industries. It does not involve testing for coproporphyrin in urine.

 

Option B. Byssinosis: Byssinosis, also known as “brown lung disease,” is caused by inhaling cotton, flax, or hemp dust, mainly affecting textile workers. It is unrelated to coproporphyrin levels in urine.

 

Option C. Bagassosis: Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling dust from bagasse, the fibrous residue of sugarcane. This condition is not associated with lead exposure or coproporphyrin levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Coproporphyrin in urine is an important screening test for lead poisoning, indicating exposure to lead, and should be followed by diagnostic tests to assess absorption.

questions.text: Mid-year population is the denominator in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CDR

 

Explanation:

 

The mid-year population is used as the denominator to calculate the Crude Death Rate (CDR). The CDR is calculated as the total number of deaths divided by the mid-year population, multiplied by 1,000.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GFR (General Fertility Rate) - This option is incorrect because. It is calculated as Annual number of live births per 1000 women of childbearing age (15–49 years) mid-year population

 

Option C. MMR (Maternal Mortality Ratio) - This option is incorrect because the MMR is calculated as maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, not using the mid-year population as the denominator.

 

Option D. NMR (Neonatal Mortality Rate) - This option is incorrect because the NMR is calculated as neonatal deaths per 1,000 live births, not using the mid-year population as the denominator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mid-year population is the denominator used in the calculation of the Crude Death Rate (CDR), which represents the total number of deaths per 1,000 population in a given year or period.

questions.text: A patient with a painless expanding annular plaque with scarring at the center present on the buttocks. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lupus vulgaris

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is lupus vulgaris. Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis. It typically presents as a painless, expanding annular plaque with scarring at the center. The lesion often advances at one edge while showing atrophy or scarring at the center or the other edge. This characteristic appearance helps in distinguishing it from other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tinea: Tinea typically presents as an annular plaque with central clearing, not central scarring.

 

Option C. Psoriasis: Psoriasis usually presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales. It does not present with the annular configuration and central scarring described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus vulgaris, the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis, presents as a painless, expanding annular plaque with central scarring. This characteristic appearance is crucial for distinguishing it from other dermatological conditions such as tinea and psoriasis. ​​

questions.text: What is the most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing in adults? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mapleson A

 

Most effective Mapleson circuit for adults:

 

  • Spontaneous breathing = Mapleson A or Magill's circuit
  • Controlled breathing = Mapleson D or Bain's circuit

 

Most effective Mapleson circuit for pediatrics – Mapleson F circuit

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing in adults is Mapleson A.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 613

questions.text: Multiple Lisch nodules are a feature of which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

 

Lisch nodules are melanocytic hamartomas found on the iris and are a hallmark of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are usually benign and do not affect vision. However, their presence is a key diagnostic criterion for NF1. Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous (benign) tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas), cafe-au-lait macules (light brown skin spots), and skin fold freckling. Another significant feature is plexiform neurofibroma, which can present congenitally.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: This is incorrect. Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by different skin lesions such as hypomelanotic macules (ash leaf spots), facial angiofibromas, and Shagreen patches. Lisch nodules are not associated with this condition.

 

Option C. Leprosy: This is incorrect. Leprosy (Hansen's disease) primarily affects the skin, nerves, and mucous membranes, but it does not involve the development of Lisch nodules.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: This is incorrect. Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas, often affecting the lungs and lymph nodes, but not associated with Lisch nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lisch nodules are pigmented iris hamartomas specific to Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and are an important diagnostic feature of this condition.

questions.text: A farmer with a history of prick injury came with the complaint: swelling of the foot with sinus tracts showing pus discharge, which showed white granules and gram-positive filamentous structures were noted on microscopy. What is the most likely causative organism associated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nocardia brasiliensis

 

This clinical scenario involving a farmer, a common occupation associated with exposure to organisms causing subcutaneous infections. The key clues here are:

 

  1. Prick injury: Suggests a subcutaneous mycosis or actinomycetoma.
  2. Swelling of the foot with sinus tracts, pus discharge, and white granules: These are characteristic features of mycetoma, also known as Madura foot.
  3. Gram-positive filamentous structures on microscopy: This is a hallmark of actinomycetoma, specifically caused by bacterial agents like Nocardia brasiliensis.

 

Mycetoma is classified into two types based on the causative organism: Actinomycetoma and Eumycetoma

 

 

Given the presence of gram-positive filamentous structures and white granules, the most likely causative organism is Nocardia brasiliensis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Incorrect because it causes sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous mycosis, but does not produce granules or gram-positive filamentous structures.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: Incorrect because, although it is gram-positive and can cause abscesses and sinus tracts, it does not form filamentous structures and is not typically associated with granules as seen in mycetoma.

 

Option D. Aspergillus: Incorrect because it is a fungus that can cause invasive infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but does not match the presentation described (i.e., white granules and gram-positive filaments).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma, or Madura foot, caused by Nocardia brasiliensis, presents with swelling, sinus tracts, white granules, and gram-positive filamentous structures on microscopy, distinguishing it from eumycetoma and other subcutaneous infections.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing implant surgery for his upper limb. On giving general anesthesia he develops tachycardia, sudden raise in body temperature and rigidity of muscles. What drug is most likely to have caused this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Halothane

 

The symptoms described in the scenario—tachycardia, hyperthermia, and muscle rigidity—are classic signs of malignant hyperthermia, a life-threatening condition that can be triggered by certain anesthetic agents, most notably volatile anesthetics like halothane and depolarizing muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine. Halothane is one of the most well-known triggers of malignant hyperthermia, especially in genetically susceptible individuals. The condition is due to an abnormal release of calcium in muscle cells, leading to intense muscle contractions, increased metabolism, and excessive heat production.

 

Other Options:
